Study population selection 16 We extracted and included all locally transmitted Covid-19 confirmed cases 17 from the publicized government investigation reports from six Asian 18 countries/areas, including Hong Kong, Japan, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, 19 and Vietnam. These countries/areas were selected since they shared some 20 common temporo-spatial characteristics. First, they are proximal to Mainland 21 China, where the first outbreak of Covid-19 was reported. Second, the first 22 cases of these countries/areas were imported cases from Mainland China in 23 mid-January. Third, the first locally transmitted cases in these countries/areas 24 were identified around late January to early February. We followed each 25 . One novel finding of this study is that the early 5 transmissions were highly related to some occupations beyond healthcare 6 settings, including taxi driver, salesperson, tour guide, and housekeeper and 7 cleaner. Taxi drivers, salespersons and tour guides are at higher risk because 8 of frequent contact with travelers. In fact, one of the earliest locally transmitted 9 cases in Taiwan was a taxi driver who took a passenger returning from 10 mainland China. This case led to a family cluster of Covid-19 with four more 11 locally transmitted cases[17]. Another example was an infected worker 12 involved in a reported cluster leading to three more local cases within a 13 household in Singapore [4]. On the other hand, housekeepers and cleaners14

The lower rate of HCW and the21 occurrence time lags among HCWs likely reflects improved triage, screening 22 and isolation of Covid-19 patients in the healthcare setting, as well as better 23 personal protective equipment (PPE) and hygiene among HCWs once 24 knowledge and experience with outbreaks increase [19-21]. , among the occupations are often neglected, and the workers are 7 less likely to have PPEs or proper infection control in their workplaces. 8 Second, it is much challenging to trace back the infection source of the non-9 HCW cases compared to the HCW cases, indicating the urging need of 10 precautions for the high-risk population. Third, many of these occupations are 11 impossible to work remotely and the workers may not benefit from the 12 measures of worker-protection, such as government-imposed shutdown or 13 work-from-home order. Fourth, many of the high-risk workers are in relatively 14 lower socioeconomic status (SES), which is a risk factor of having Covid-19 15 infection and worse disease outcomes [23]. People from the lower ends of the 16 society are more susceptible to infectious outbreaks due to poorer living and 17 working conditions [24,25]. They are more likely to have chronic health 18 conditions which could lead to more severe consequences after being 19 infected [26]. Protecting the high-risk workers could provide an opportunity to 20 prevent the spread of the disease and to mitigate the deepening of contribution of non-HCW to the Covid-19 locally transmitted 24 cases emphasizes the importance of implementing effective infection control 25 .

FIGREF9.text: has some strengths. First, the data were extracted from the 6 investigation reports published by the government of six countries/areas,7 which should be valid[28,29], and pooling of multi-county sources prevented 8 the results from being skewed by single-country experience. Regarding the 9 different case reporting system in Japan, we did further sensitivity analysis 10 using the data from other five countries/areas and found similar temporal 11 distribution patterns, which strengthened our conclusions. Second, every 12 eligible case was reviewed by two occupational physicians and a physician 13 epidemiologist with agreements on work-relatedness after thorough inspection 14 of case reports. Moreover, we followed each country/area for 40 days, which 15 allowed us to obtain comparable data for pooled analysis and illustrate trends 16 of transmission in early stages of Covid-19 outbreak.17 18 Nonetheless, there are limitations of this study. First, there were 19 discrepancies in reporting and investigation across the countries/areas. Cases 20 without reported occupational history could potentially lead to underestimation 21 in the analysis. Second, the report date of a case could be different to the 22 date of getting infected and having symptoms. However, the information bias 23

TABREF1.text: Categorization of work-related casesEach case report was reviewed by two occupational physicians and categorized by the work-relatedness. Subsequently, the possible work-related cases were grouped into two categories based on whether the transmission Category 1: had clear close contact with a confirmed case due to work,10 such as a registered nurse having a history of directly caring for a 11 patient who is an index confirmed case; and 12 2. Category 2: unknown transmission source; no apparent contact history 13 but likely to be infected in the working environment, such as an airport 14 taxi driver without clear contact history to any confirmed case. The cases with occupations and contact histories were coded according to the 17 International Standard Classification of Occupations, 2008 (ISCO-08) [15]. We 18 defined health professionals, medical doctors, and nursing professionals as 19 healthcare workers (HCWs) regarding the high risk of infection due to the 20 work.
